question: Researchers from Yale University have found a reason for chocoholic pregnant women to rejoice!They have found that women with the highest levels of theobromine, one ingredient in dark chocolate, are 69% less likely to develop pre-eclampsia then women with the lowest levels."Earlier research in adults has shown that theobromine helps reduce blood pressure an ease stress on the cardiovascular system", says study author Elizabeth Triche, Ph.D, a research scientist at Yale.Downside?  Chocolate, though a substance I consider to be the basis of life as we know it in this universe, does have calories.  To limit calories, while still getting the protective benefits, Triche advises limiting your intake to about 1 ounce of dark chocolate or 1 cup of hot cocoa (real cocoa) a day.*You will find a recipe for Peeks Skinny Hot Cocoa on the Healthy Cooking Community*
title: Chocolate and Pre-Eclampsia--Good News for chocolate lovers!
